About

Geoffrey Manda, MBBS, MSc

PhD Research Fellow in Biostatistics & Epidemiology | Queen Mary University of London
Editor, CausalAtlas.org – Advancing Resources on Causality and Causal Inference

Professional Summary

I am a PhD Research Fellow in Biostatistics and Epidemiology at Queen Mary University of London, advised by Professors Andrew Prendergast and Melanie Smuk. My PhD research focuses on establishing statistical and algorithmic foundations for discovery and decision-making in systems governed by underlying causal rules. In particular, I develop and apply tools from mathematical statistics and machine learning (ML) to understand causal relationships from data, model and extrapolate to predict the effects of interventions, and select informative interventions and/or policies for experimental or trial design.

Motivated by problems in clinical care, pharmacology, and cell biology, this work aims to accelerate mechanistic discovery and translation to biomedical engineering and public health policy. My research is supported by the prestigious CREATE PhD Fellowship.

I bring over eight years of experience across clinical practice and public health research, including roles with the World Health Organization (WHO) and as Research Project Manager at Kamuzu University of Health Sciences, collaborating with AMREF Health Africa, UNICEF, the World Bank Group, USAID, and the Malawi Ministry of Health to shape evidence-based policy and implement high-impact interventions in HIV, TB, Nutrition, Oncology, Maternal-Child health, and health systems.

Research Focus

Causal Inference & Discovery

Developing statistical and algorithmic foundations for causal discovery from observational data, integrating methods from graphical models, structural equation modeling, and machine learning.

Biostatistics & Clinical Trials

Advanced statistical methods for clinical trials, observational studies, survival analysis, and longitudinal data analysis with applications in pediatric nutrition and oncology.

Public Health & Health Systems

Evidence synthesis, program design and evaluation, mixed methods research, and health policy development for maternal-child health, infectious diseases, and nutrition interventions.

Education

PhD in Nutrition (Biostatistics & Epidemiology)

Queen Mary University of London | September 2025 – September 2029

Thesis: Integrating Causal Inference, Causal Discovery, and State Transition Modelling to Investigate Long-Term Recovery Trajectories in Children Convalescing from Severe Acute Malnutrition
Advisors: Prof. Andrew Prendergast & Prof. Melanie Smuk
Funding: CREATE PhD Fellowship (£74,000)

MSc in Public Health

London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine | September 2020 – September 2021

Thesis: Determinants of neonatal mortality in Malawi, 2019-2020: A spatiotemporal analysis of the NEST360° baseline data
Supervisors: Prof. Kelias Msyamboza (WHO) & Prof. Eric Ohuma (LSHTM)
GPA: 4.0/5.0 | Funding: Commonwealth Masters Scholarship (£40,000)

MBBS (Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery)

University of Malawi, College of Medicine | January 2010 – July 2015

Thesis: Cancer survival in Malawi: A retrospective cohort study (Distinction grade)
US Doctor of Medicine (MD) Equivalent

Current & Recent Positions

Editor, CausalAtlas.org

Leading editorial efforts for a comprehensive resource platform providing tutorials, tools, and methodological guidance on causality, causal inference, and causal discovery for researchers and practitioners.

Visit CausalAtlas.org →

Biostatistical Consultant

Ripple Global Health Research Institute | 2024-2025
Leading statistical analysis for nutrition clinical trials in Mali and Malawi, applying GAMs, SEM, and causal methods to inform program optimization.

Systematic Review Consultant

World Health Organization (WHO) | 2022-2023
Conducted systematic reviews and meta-analyses that directly informed the 2023 WHO guideline updates on management of acute malnutrition.

Highlighting key research contributions in epidemiology, pediatric oncology, and public health.
